questions.question_text: What is the best estimate of the wavelength of green light? A 260 nm  B 540 nm  C 780 nm  D 920 nm

In an electric circuit, an ammeter reads 2 μA. In a second circuit, the ammeter reads 1 mA. How many times larger is the current in the second circuit compared with the current in the first circuit? A 500  B 5000  C 500 000  D 5 000 000

A set of repeated measurements is made of a fixed quantity. An average of these measurements is calculated. What is the effect of averaging on the random error and the systematic error in the measurements? A Random error and systematic error are both reduced.  B Random error and systematic error are both unaffected.  C Random error is reduced but systematic error is unaffected.  D Random error is unaffected but systematic error is reduced.

A student estimates the maximum speed of some different moving objects. Which maximum speed is not a reasonable estimate? A container ship: 10 m s–1  B Olympic sprinter: 0.1 km s–1  C racing car: 9000 cm s–1  D snail: 0.01 km h–1
Which quantity is an SI base quantity? A force  B newton  C second  D time

A student takes measurements to determine the constant acceleration of a model car from rest. Displacement 16.5 m ± 0.1 m, time 15.0 s ± 1.0 s, using s = ½at². What is the acceleration and its absolute uncertainty? A (0.11 ± 0.01) m s–2  B (0.11 ± 0.02) m s–2  C (0.15 ± 0.01) m s–2  D (0.15 ± 0.02) m s–2
What is a reasonable estimate of the cross-sectional area of the wire in a paper clip? A 1 × 10–3 m2  B 8 × 10–5 m2  C 8 × 10–7 m2  D 1 × 10–9 m2
Which quantity is not an SI base quantity? A charge  B mass  C temperature  D time

A student determines the acceleration of free fall by using a small metal ball… Which statement about errors in the experiment is correct? A The random error can be reduced by adding the diameter of the ball to the distance PQ.  B The random error can be reduced by subtracting the diameter of the ball from the distance PQ.  C The systematic error can be reduced by adding the diameter of the ball to the distance PQ.  D The systematic error can be reduced by subtracting the diameter of the ball from the distance PQ.
Table 1.1 lists some physical quantities. Complete the table by placing a tick (✓) next to the scalar quantities. (acceleration, charge, momentum, power, upthrust)

A uniform cylinder has diameter D, length L and mass M. The density ρ of the cylinder is ρ = 4M / (π D^2 L). Table 1.2 shows measurements with uncertainties. (i) Calculate the percentage uncertainties in D and L and write them in Table 1.2.
(ii) Calculate the density of the cylinder. Give your answer to three significant figures.
(iii) Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the density.
Compare scalar and vector quantities.

The radius of a small sphere is determined from a measurement of the volume of the sphere. The sphere is submerged in water, displacing some of the water into a measuring cylinder as shown in Fig. 1.1. The measured volume of displaced water is (28.0 ± 0.5) cm^3. (i) Calculate the radius, in cm, of the sphere.
(ii) Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the radius of the sphere.
(a)(i) Define pressure.
(a)(ii) Use the answer to (a)(i) to show that the SI base units of pressure are kg m–1 s–2.

(b) A horizontal pipe has length L and circular cross-section radius R. A liquid of density ρ flows through the pipe. The mass m of liquid flowing in time t is m = [π(p2 – p1)R^4 ρ t] / (8 k L), where p1 and p2 are the end pressures and k is a constant. Determine the SI base units of k.
(c) In an experiment to determine k, L and R each have a percentage uncertainty of 2%. State and explain, quantitatively, which of these contributes more to the percentage uncertainty in k.
(a)(i) Define power.
(a)(ii) Use the definition of power to show that the SI base units of power are kg m^2 s^–3.

(b) The intensity I of a sound wave moving through a gas is given by I = f^2 A^2 v k, where f is the frequency, A is the amplitude, v is the speed and k is a constant that depends on the gas. Determine the SI base units of k.
What must be included in a record of a physical quantity? A an integer value for the quantity  B an SI unit  C a numerical value for the quantity  D a unit expressed in base units
What is the ohm expressed in SI base units? A kg m2 s–3 A–2  B kg–1 m–2 s3 A2  C J C–1 A–1  D W A–2

A desk has a true width of 50.0 cm. Two students, X and Y, measure the width of the desk. Student X uses a tape measure and records a width of (49.5 ± 0.5) cm. Student Y uses a metre rule and records a width of (51.4 ± 0.1) cm. Which statement about the measurement of student X is correct? A It is less accurate and less precise than the measurement of student Y.  B It is less accurate but more precise than the measurement of student Y.  C It is more accurate and more precise than the measurement of student Y.  D It is more accurate but less precise than the measurement of student Y.
Gm, Tm, μm and pm are units of length. Which is the largest and which is the smallest? A Gm & μm  B Gm & pm  C Tm & μm  D Tm & pm
Sphere: mass = (32.5 ± 0.1) g, diameter = (1.87 ± 0.04) cm. These values determine density. What is the percentage uncertainty in density? A 2.4%  B 4.6%  C 6.1%  D 6.7%
Which unit is not an SI base unit? A A  B kg  C C  D s
What is the best estimate of the number of atoms in a piece of metal of volume 50 cm3? A 5 × 10^15  B 5 × 10^25  C 5 × 10^29  D 5 × 10^31

A copper pipe has a true diameter of 42.03 mm. A builder measures the diameter of the pipe five times using digital calipers (48.01, 47.99, 48.01, 48.00, 47.99 mm). What describes the builder’s measurements? A accurate and precise  B accurate but not precise  C not precise and not accurate  D precise but not accurate

Which statement about physical quantities is correct? A A physical quantity does not always have a magnitude or a unit. B A physical quantity must always have a magnitude but does not always have a unit. C A physical quantity must always have a unit but does not always have a magnitude. D A physical quantity must always have a magnitude and a unit.
What is a reasonable estimate of the mass of a solid sphere of copper that has a diameter of 60 cm? A 0.1 kg B 10 kg C 1000 kg D 100 000 kg
The power output P of a star can be modelled with P = σAT^4. What are the SI base units of σ? A kg s–2 K–4 B kg s–3 K–4 C kg m–1 s–2 K–4 D kg m–1 s–3 K–4
A physical quantity consists of a magnitude and a unit. Which row does not show a correct combination of a quantity and its unit?  A mass gram  B length metre  C charge ampere  D temperature kelvin
A small car travels in a town. What is a reasonable estimate of the kinetic energy of the car?  A 5 × 10^4 J  B 5 × 10^7 J  C 5 × 10^10 J  D 5 × 10^13 J

A solid bar has a square cross-section. Its length is measured as 50.0 ± 0.2 cm and its width is measured as 2.00 ± 0.01 cm. These values are used to calculate the volume of the bar. What is the percentage uncertainty in the calculated volume?  A ± 0.21%  B ± 0.22%  C ± 0.90%  D ± 1.4%
What are the SI base units for the moment of a force? A kg m–1 s2  B kg s–2  C kg m s–2  D kg m2 s–2

Which statement about vector quantities is correct? A g is a vector because magnitude is constant  B °C is a vector because it can be ±  C Time is a vector because it goes forwards  D Weight is a vector because it has a direction
A block’s density is 2.50 g cm–3 from mass and dimensions with given uncertainties. What is the uncertainty in this result? A ±0.01  B ±0.02  C ±0.05  D ±0.13 g cm–3
What is a reasonable estimate of the volume of one page of this paper? A 60 mm3  B 600 mm3  C 6000 mm3  D 60 000 mm3
Define density.
A cuboidal glass block has mass m and side lengths x, y and z as in Fig. 1.1. Using the measurements in Table 1.1, determine the density of the glass.
Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the density.
The true density differs from (b)(i) due to a systematic error in the measurements. Suggest one possible cause of this systematic error.
What is equal to 0.000005 J? A 5 mJ  B 5 MJ  C 5 μJ  D 5 nJ

The measurement of a physical quantity may be subject to random errors and to systematic errors. Which statement is correct? A A systematic error cannot be reduced by adjusting the apparatus. B A systematic error results in a different reading each time the measurement is taken. C Random errors are always caused by the person taking the measurement. D Random errors can be reduced by taking the average of several measurements.

Two physical quantities combined together as a product can produce a scalar quantity or a vector quantity. Which product of two quantities produces a scalar quantity? A (force) × (displacement of an object in the direction of the force) B (mass) × (acceleration of the mass) C (pressure) × (area on which the pressure acts) D (velocity) × (time for which an object has that velocity)

What is a scalar quantity? A a quantity that can be represented as two perpendicular components  B a quantity that does not require a unit  C a quantity without a direction  D a quantity without a magnitude
X has 2% uncertainty, Y has 4% uncertainty. W is calculated from X and Y. W has 8% uncertainty. What could be the relationship between W, X and Y? A W = XY  B W = 2XY  C W = X/2Y  D W = 2X/Y
The list below shows some SI quantities. Underline the quantity that is not an SI base quantity: charge, current, length, time.
A square solar panel has sides of length 1300 mm. Light is incident normally. (i) The power of the light incident on the panel is 750 W. Calculate the intensity of the light.
(ii) The percentage uncertainty in the incident power is ±3%. The uncertainty in the length of each side is ±5 mm. Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the intensity of the light.
(iii) The useful power output of the solar panel is 160 W. Calculate the percentage efficiency of the solar panel.

(iv) Another square solar panel, with shorter sides, is placed so that light of the same intensity is incident normally. The new panel has the same power output as the original panel. State and explain whether the efficiency of the new panel is greater than, less than or the same as the efficiency of the original panel.
Which unit is an SI base unit? A ampere  B coulomb  C degree Celsius  D gram
Which of the following could have the same units as force? A energy/distance  B energy/time  C momentum × distance  D momentum × time
The velocity changes from u to v. Which single vector represents the change in velocity of the object? (vector diagrams shown: options A–D)
Underline all the SI base units in the following list: ampere, coulomb, current, kelvin, newton.

A toy car moves in a horizontal straight line. Its displacement s is given by s = v^2 / (2a), where a is the acceleration and v is the final velocity. State two conditions that must apply to the motion of the car for the equation to be valid.
An experiment to determine a uses: s = 3.89 m ± 0.5% and v = 2.75 m s–1 ± 0.8%. (i) Calculate the acceleration a.
(ii) Determine the percentage uncertainty, to two significant figures, in a.
(iii) Using your answers to (c)(i) and (c)(ii), determine the absolute uncertainty in a.
What represents a physical quantity? A 3.0  B kilogram  C 7.0 N  D 40%

The relationship between the variables D and T is given by the equation 1/T = b/D + c, where b and c are constants. The unit of D is m^2 and the unit of T is s. What are the units of b and c? (A m s, s; B m s–1, s–1; C m–1 s, s; D m–1 s–1, s–1)

A hollow cylinder, open at both ends, has radius (3.0 ± 0.1) cm and length (15.0 ± 0.1) cm. What is the value, with its absolute uncertainty, of the surface area of the cylinder? A (280 ± 10) cm^2  B (282.7 ± 0.2) cm^2  C (420 ± 30) cm^2  D (424.1 ± 0.3) cm^2
Table 1.1 lists some SI quantities. Complete the table by indicating with a tick (✓) which rows are SI base quantities.
Use the definition of power to determine its SI base units.
A light meter measures intensity for daylight incident normally on a sensor of area 2.2 cm^2. The meter reads 950 W m–2. Calculate the power of the daylight incident on the sensor.
Explain what is meant by the accuracy of a measured value.

Two solid cubes, A and B, are measured to determine the density of their materials. Table 1.1 shows the measurements for cube A: length of side (1.53 ± 0.01) cm; mass (31.3 ± 0.5) g. (i) Show that the calculated density of the material of cube A is 8.7 × 10^3 kg m–3.
(ii) Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the density of the material of cube A.
(iii) The density of the material of cube B is determined to be 9.2 × 10^3 kg m–3 ± 6%. State and explain whether cube A and cube B could be made from the same material.
Which row shows a physical quantity and its base unit in the SI system? A current A  B force N  C mass g  D temperature °C
Which quantity is a scalar quantity? A force  B momentum  C velocity  D work

What is the effect of a systematic error on the measurement of a physical quantity? A It limits the precision of the measured value. B It limits the range of values obtained in repeated measurements. C It results in repeated measurements having different values from each other. D It results in the measured value being different from the correct value.

Which statement about mass is correct? A Mass has a magnitude and a direction.  B Mass resists changes in motion.  C The greater the mass of an object, the greater its acceleration when falling in a vacuum.  D The mass of an object depends on its location.

A snooker ball has a mass of 200 g. It hits the cushion of a snooker table and rebounds along its original path. The ball arrives at the cushion with a speed of 14.0 m s–1 and then leaves it with a speed of 7.0 m s–1. The ball and the cushion are in contact for a time of 0.60 s. What is the average force exerted on the ball by the cushion? A 1.4 N  B 2.3 N  C 4.2 N  D 7.0 N

A ball falls from rest through air and eventually reaches a constant velocity. For this fall, forces X and Y vary with time as shown. What could be forces X and Y ? A air resistance / resultant force  B air resistance / weight  C upthrust / resultant force  D upthrust / weight

An object X (0.30 kg) travels at 3.0 m s–1 on a horizontal frictionless surface and collides with stationary object Y (0.50 kg). After, X is 2.0 m s–1 at 60° to initial direction; Y moves at speed v at 41° to the initial direction. What is v? A 0.80 m s–1  B 1.2 m s–1  C 1.6 m s–1  D 1.8 m s–1

An aeroplane moves at constant speed along a straight line at angle θ to the horizontal with thrust T, weight W, lift L and resistive force R. Which two equations must be correct? A L = W cos θ and T = R + W sin θ  B L = W sin θ and T = R + W cos θ  C L = W cos θ and T = R − W sin θ  D L = W sin θ and T = R − W cos θ

A resultant force causes an object to accelerate. What is equal to the resultant force? A acceleration per unit mass  B change in kinetic energy per unit time  C change in momentum per unit time  D change in velocity per unit time

An object falls from a stationary helicopter and reaches terminal velocity. What happens to the acceleration between leaving the helicopter and reaching terminal velocity? A decreases to 9.81 m s–2  B decreases to zero  C increases to 9.81 m s–2  D remains constant at 9.81 m s–2

Two balls, masses m and 2m, with initial velocities 2v and v respectively, collide head-on in a vacuum. After collision, mass m rebounds left with speed v. What is the loss of kinetic energy? A (4/3)mv²  B (2/3)mv²  C (4/9)mv²  D (2/9)mv²

Two blocks (0.20 kg on rough surface and 0.50 kg hanging) are connected over a frictionless pulley. On release, acceleration magnitude is 2.0 m s–2. What is the magnitude of the frictional force on the 0.20 kg block? A 3.5 N  B 3.9 N  C 4.5 N  D 6.3 N
The diagram shows two coplanar forces, P and Q… Force R is given by R = Q – P. Which diagram represents R ? (Options A–D with vector diagrams.)

A man stands in a lift that is accelerating vertically downwards… Which statement describes the force exerted by the man on the floor? A It is equal to the weight of the man.  B It is greater than the force exerted by the floor on the man.  C It is less than the force exerted by the floor on the man.  D It is less than the weight of the man.

A ball of mass 200 g is thrown horizontally at 20 m s–1 against a vertical wall… in contact 0.10 s… rebounds at 10 m s–1. What is the average force exerted by the wall on the ball during the collision? A 20 N  B 60 N  C 20 kN  D 60 kN

Two objects move towards each other along the same straight line… After colliding, they stick together and are stationary. Which statement must be correct? A The total kinetic energy…  B The total momentum…  C The two objects have equal mass.  D The two objects have the same speed before the collision.

A ball Y moves along a horizontal frictionless surface and collides with a ball Z. Ball Y (0.25 kg) initially moves along line PQ; ball Z (mass mZ) is initially stationary. After the collision, Y has 3.7 m s–1 at 27° to PQ; Z has 5.5 m s–1 at 44° to PQ. (a)(i) Calculate the component of the final momentum of ball Y in the direction perpendicular to line PQ.
(a)(ii) By considering the component of the final momentum of each ball in the direction perpendicular to line PQ, calculate mZ.

(a)(iii) During the collision, the average force exerted on Y by Z is FY and the average force exerted on Z by Y is FZ. Compare the magnitudes and directions of FY and FZ. Numerical values are not required.

(b) Two blocks, A and B, move directly towards each other along a horizontal frictionless surface. The blocks collide perfectly elastically. Before the collision, A has 4 m s–1 and B has 6 m s–1. After the collision, B moves back along its original path with 2 m s–1. Calculate the speed of block A after the collision.
A trolley A moves towards trolley B; they collide elastically and separate. (a) State what is represented by the area under a velocity–time graph.
(b)(i) Using Table 3.1 and Fig. 3.2, determine the acceleration of trolley B during the collision.
(b)(ii) Determine the magnitude and direction of the final velocity of trolley A.
(c) On Fig. 3.2, sketch the variation of the velocity of trolley A with time t from t = 0 to t = 0.50 s.
(a) State the principle of conservation of momentum.
(b) A stationary firework explodes into three fragments A (mass 3m, 4.0 m s–1), B (mass 2m, 6.0 m s–1 at right angles to A) and C (mass m, speed v at angle θ). (i) Calculate the angle θ.
(b)(ii) Calculate the speed v.
(c) The firework contains 5.0 g of a chemical with energy per unit mass 700 J kg–1. All the chemical energy becomes kinetic energy of the fragments. (i) Show that the total chemical energy is 3.5 J.
(c)(ii) Calculate the mass m.
(a)(i) Define force.
(a)(ii) Using Fig. 3.2 for X(t), determine the change in momentum of the block from t = 0 to t = 3.0 s.
(b)(i) Describe and explain the motion of the block between t = 3.0 s and t = 6.0 s.
(b)(ii) Force X produces total power 2.0 W when moving the block between t = 3.0 s and t = 6.0 s. Calculate the distance moved in this interval.
(c) The block is at rest at t = 0. On Fig. 3.3, sketch the variation of momentum with time from t = 0 to t = 6.0 s (no numerical values required).

A block is pulled in a straight line along a rough horizontal surface by a varying force X, as shown in Fig. 3.1. Air resistance is negligible. Assume that the frictional force exerted on the block by the surface is constant and has magnitude 2.0 N. The variation with time t of the momentum p of the block is shown in Fig. 3.2. (a) State Newton’s second law of motion.
(b)(i) Use Fig. 3.2 to determine, for the block at time t = 2.0 s, the magnitude of the resultant force on the block.
(b)(ii) Use Fig. 3.2 to determine, for the block at time t = 2.0 s, the magnitude of the force X.
(c) On Fig. 3.3, sketch a graph to show the variation of force X with time t from t = 0 to t = 6.0 s.

A device for spraying paint ejects paint at 2.5 m s–1 through 400 holes, each of area 0.4 mm2. The density of the paint is 900 kg m–3. What is the horizontal force required to hold the device stationary as it ejects the paint? A 0.36 N  B 0.90 N  C 2.3 N  D 900 N
Each diagram illustrates a pair of forces of equal magnitude. Which diagram gives an example of a pair of forces that is described by Newton’s third law of motion? (options A–D with sketches)

Two balls of identical shape and size but different masses are falling through the same liquid. The sum of the drag force and upthrust acting on each ball is equal to its weight. Which statement about the two balls is correct? A The heavier ball has a larger acceleration than the lighter ball.  B The heavier ball has a smaller deceleration than the lighter ball.  C The heavier ball is falling at the same speed as the lighter ball.  D The heavier ball is falling at a larger speed than the lighter ball.

A perfectly elastic collision occurs between two objects X and Y. The mass of X is m and the mass of Y is 4m. X travels at speed v before the collision and speed (3/5)v in the opposite direction after; Y is stationary before. What is the kinetic energy of Y after the collision? A (8/10)mv2  B (34/50)mv2  C (16/50)mv2  D (1/5)mv2
An aircraft has horizontal thrust and a wind force (vector diagram shown). Which vector is the resultant horizontal force? A B C D
Which statement describes the mass of an object? A the force due to gravity  B momentum before a collision  C resistance to changes in motion  D weight measured by a balance

A box slides with increasing speed down a rough slope from P to Q; friction is constant. Which row gives the change in magnitude of acceleration and total resistive force? A increases/decreases  B decreases/decreases  C increases/increases  D decreases/increases

Two balls X and Y approach each other on a line and collide elastically. Initial speeds uX and uY; after collision vX and vY as shown. Which equation is correct? A uX+uY=vX+vY  B uX+uY=vX−vY  C uX−uY=vX+vY  D uX−uY=vX−vY

A camera drone of mass 1.20 kg hovers at a fixed point. In 1.00 s, each of four propellers pushes 0.400 kg of air vertically downwards (assume air above is stationary). What is the speed of the air leaving each propeller? A 0.750 m s–1  B 3.00 m s–1  C 7.36 m s–1  D 29.4 m s–1

A box rests on the Earth. Newton’s third law describes how forces of the same type act in pairs. One of the forces of a pair is the weight W of the box. Which arrow represents the other force of this pair? (diagram as in paper, options A–D)
A small ball is released at the surface of oil and falls through the oil. The ball has velocity v and viscous force F acts on it. Which graph could show the variation with v of F? (options A–D)

An object of mass m moving at speed u along a frictionless horizontal surface collides head-on with a stationary object of mass 4m. After the collision, the object of mass m rebounds along its initial path with one-quarter of its initial kinetic energy. What is the speed of the object of mass 4m after the collision? A u/8  B 3u/16  C 5u/16  D 3u/8
Two forces, each of 10 N, act at a point P. The angle between the directions of the forces is 120°. What is the magnitude of the resultant force? A 5 N  B 10 N  C 17 N  D 20 N

In which example is it not possible for the underlined object to be in equilibrium? A An aeroplane climbs at a steady rate. B An aeroplane tows a glider at a constant altitude. C A speedboat changes direction at a constant speed. D Two boats tow a ship into harbour.
The graph shows momentum p versus time t for a car. What is the resultant force on the car at t = 10 s? A 0 B 1500 N C 2000 N D 4000 N

Two objects X and Y form an isolated system. X and Y collide and then separate. The mass of X is greater than the mass of Y. Which statement is correct? A Δp of Y > Δp of X. B Force on Y > force on X. C The forces that X and Y exert on each other act for the same length of time. D The forces that X and Y exert on each other are gravitational forces only.

Which row states whether total momentum and total kinetic energy are conserved in an inelastic collision in which there are no external forces? A conserved/conserved B conserved/not conserved C not conserved/conserved D not conserved/not conserved

A tennis ball is thrown vertically upwards and returns to the start point. Air resistance is significant. At which position is the resultant force on the ball greatest? A just after release B halfway up C at highest point D halfway down

A moving object strikes a stationary object. The collision is inelastic. The objects move off together. Assume that the two objects form an isolated system. Which row shows the possible values of total momentum and total kinetic energy for the system before and after the collision? (Table A–D as in paper.)

The graph shows how a quantity Y varies with a quantity X for an object falling vertically at its terminal velocity towards the surface of the Earth. Which quantities could X and Y represent?  A time, acceleration  B time, height above surface  C distance moved, kinetic energy  D distance moved, velocity

A ball of mass 2.0 kg travels horizontally with a speed of 4.0 m s–1. The ball collides with a wall and rebounds in the opposite direction with a speed of 2.8 m s–1. The time of the collision is 150 ms. What is the average force exerted on the wall?  A 16 N  B 37 N  C 53 N  D 91 N

Two train carriages each of mass 5000 kg roll toward one another on a horizontal frictionless track. One is travelling at a speed of 2.00 m s–1 and the other at a speed of 1.00 m s–1. They collide and join together. What is the kinetic energy lost during the collision?  A 1250 J  B 7500 J  C 11 250 J  D 12 500 J
A 1200 kg car has momentum 18 000 kg m s–1. What is its kinetic energy? A 4.65 kJ  B 6.57 kJ  C 135 kJ  D 270 kJ
Ladder on frictionless ground leaning on rough wall begins to slide. Which diagram shows force directions P, W, R?
Lift and counterbalance with given masses. What is the magnitude of the acceleration of the car (single passenger), pulley free to rotate? A 0.032  B 0.32  C 0.61  D 0.65 m s–2
Ball mass m hit by bat, leaves with velocity v; contact time Δt. Average force on the ball? A mvΔt  B mv/Δt  C ½m v Δt  D ½ mv/Δt
Disc M at speed u collides with 4M stationary; after collision given directions and 4.0 m s–1 for 4M. Find initial u. Options A–D.
Object dropped on Earth from 2.0 m; on Moon from 4.0 m (g_Moon ≈ 0.16g). Ratio of impact speeds (Moon/Earth)? A 1.8  B 2.5  C 3.1  D 3.5
Bungee jumper v–t graph with points P, Q, R. Where is jumper at rest? Where is acceleration zero? Options table.
State the principle of conservation of momentum.

A ball X has mass 240 g and moves in a straight line on a horizontal frictionless surface with an initial speed of 16 m s–1. The ball collides with a stationary ball Y that has mass 480 g. After the collision, ball X is stationary, as shown in Fig. 2.1. (i) Show that the speed v of ball Y after the collision is 8.0 m s–1.
(ii) Calculate the change in the total kinetic energy ΔE_K of the balls due to the collision.

(c) The collision in (b) lasts for a time of 2.0 ms. Assume that the contact force between the balls is constant during this time. (i) Determine the magnitude and direction of the force exerted on ball X by ball Y during the collision.
(ii) Compare the magnitude and direction of the force exerted on ball Y by ball X during the collision with the answers in (c)(i). No further calculations are required.
Define momentum.

A child and scooter (total mass 16 kg) start from rest. She pushes once on the ground; the push lasts 1.1 s and her speed after the push is 0.60 m s–1. Determine the average resultant horizontal force during the push.
Later she travels down a slope at constant angle. At A her speed is 0.60 m s–1. She accelerates at 0.85 m s–2 along the slope for 3.7 s until point B. Calculate the distance x travelled from A to B.

At B she applies the brake with a constant force to maintain constant velocity. Point C is 18 m from B. The work done by the braking force between B and C is 250 J. (i) Determine the magnitude of the braking force.
(ii) On the provided axes, sketch the variation of the kinetic energy of the child and scooter with distance travelled from A to C (numerical values not required).
Define linear momentum.
A car of mass 1800 kg moves in a straight line. Fig. 2.1 shows the variation with time t of its momentum p. Calculate the maximum speed reached by the car.
Calculate the maximum kinetic energy of the car.
Show that the acceleration of the car at t = 4.0 s is 5.0 m s–2.
Determine the distance travelled by the car between t = 0 and t = 12.0 s.
On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with time t of the acceleration a of the car from t = 0 to t = 12.0 s.

A block on a frictionless surface experiences a constant force F and a constant 5.0 N resistive force while moving in the direction of F. The momentum–time graph is shown with key values. What is the magnitude of F? A 2.0 N  B 3.0 N  C 5.0 N  D 8.0 N

Newton’s third law describes two forces that are equal in magnitude and form a pair. Which description of the two forces is not correct? A They act in opposite directions. B They act on different objects. C They are the same type of force. D They cause an object to be in equilibrium.

The speed–time graph of a raindrop falling vertically through air is shown. Which statement is correct? A The acceleration decreases to produce a steady speed. B The acceleration increases as the speed increases. C The air resistance decreases as the speed increases. D The resultant force increases as the speed increases.

Which statement about a perfectly elastic collision between two objects is correct? A Total kinetic energy is conserved and the relative speed of approach equals the relative speed of separation. B Total kinetic energy is conserved but the relative speed of approach does not equal the relative speed of separation. C Total kinetic energy is not conserved and the relative speed of approach does not equal the relative speed of separation. D Total kinetic energy is not conserved but the relative speed of approach does equal the relative speed of separation.
Two satellites collide inelastically. What happens to total kinetic energy and total momentum? A conserved, conserved  B conserved, reduced  C reduced, conserved  D reduced, reduced
Reasonable estimate of the momentum of a family car travelling at 25 km h–1? A 1×10^4 kg m s–1  B 1×10^5 kg m s–1  C 1×10^6 kg m s–1  D 1×10^7 kg m s–1

A football is kicked vertically upwards through the air. What is the variation in the air resistance and the resultant force as it moves upwards? A decreases, decreases  B decreases, increases  C increases, decreases  D increases, increases
A skydiver’s velocity v varies with time t as shown on a v–t graph. (a)(i) Using the graph, state the terminal velocity of the skydiver.
(a)(ii) By drawing a suitable line on the graph, determine the acceleration of the skydiver at t = 9.0 s.

(b) The mass of the skydiver and equipment is 68 kg; upthrust is negligible. At time t1, immediately after reaching terminal velocity, the parachute is opened and a total drag force of 1800 N acts. Determine the magnitude and direction of the acceleration at t1.

(c)(i) The parachute is fully open at time t2. At a later time t3 the skydiver reaches a constant velocity of 5.7 m s–1. Describe and explain the variation with time of the magnitude of her acceleration between t2 and t3.
(c)(ii) Calculate the change in momentum of the skydiver between time t1 and time t3.

Spheres X and Y form an isolated system. Mass of Y > mass of X. Y is initially stationary. X collides elastically with Y with speed u. Which statement must be correct? (Options A–D describe post-collision speeds/rebounds relative to u.)

A 0.10 kg ball hits a stationary vertical bat with horizontal velocity 20 m s–1 and rebounds at 15 m s–1 (horizontally). What is the change in momentum of the ball? A 0.20 N s  B 0.50 N s  C 1.5 N s  D 3.5 N s
A golf club hits a ball. The graph shows force F versus time t. Which graph shows how the ball's velocity v varies with time t? (options A–D)
State the principle of conservation of momentum.

An object of mass 2m is travelling at a speed of 5.0 m s–1 in a straight line. It collides with an object of mass 3m which is initially stationary, as shown in Fig. 3.1. After the collision, the object of mass 2m moves with velocity v at an angle of 30° to its original direction of motion. The object of mass 3m moves with velocity w also at an angle of 30°, as shown in Fig. 3.2. By considering the conservation of momentum in two dimensions, calculate the magnitudes of v and w.
An object of mass 4.2 kg is travelling in a straight line at a speed of 6.0 m s–1. The object is brought to rest in a distance of 0.050 m by a constant force. Calculate the magnitude of this force.

The drag force FD acting on an object falling through air is given by FD = 1/2 C ρ A v^2, where A is cross-sectional area, v is speed in air, ρ is air density, and C is the drag coefficient. (a) Use SI base units to show that the drag coefficient has no units.
(b) A sphere falls at terminal velocity in air (upthrust negligible). On Fig. 1.1, draw and label arrows to show the directions of the two forces acting on the sphere.
(c) The mass of the sphere is 49 g. Calculate the drag force FD acting on the sphere.

(d) The sphere is falling in air at a terminal velocity of 25 in SI base units. The density of the air is 1.2 in SI base units. The diameter of the sphere is 0.060 in SI base units. Use your answer in (c) to calculate the drag coefficient C for the sphere.
(a) Block X has an initial kinetic energy of 0.30 J. Calculate the mass of block X.
(b) Determine the magnitude of the momentum of block Y after the collision.
(c) Block X exerts an average force of 7.7 N on block Y during the collision. Calculate the time that the blocks are in contact with each other.
The graph shows displacement s against time t. Which graph represents acceleration a against t?
Which expression defines force? A (mass × change in speed) × time taken  B mass × (change in speed / time taken)  C (change of momentum) × time taken  D (change of momentum / time taken)

A ship of mass 8.4 × 10^7 kg is travelling at 16.4 m s–1. Reverse thrust is used to maintain a constant stopping force of 920 000 N. How long does it take the ship to come to rest? A 15 s  B 150 s  C 25 min  D 250 min
Which velocity–time graph represents an object falling from rest through a long distance in Earth’s atmosphere?

Which statement about collisions is correct? A Kinetic energy is conserved in all collisions. B Momentum is conserved only in perfectly elastic collisions. C For perfectly elastic collisions, the relative speed of approach equals the relative speed of separation. D Two objects of different masses exert forces of different magnitudes on each other.

A snooker ball of mass 0.20 kg changes its direction of motion by 90°. Its speed is 0.40 m s–1 before the collision and 0.30 m s–1 after the collision. What is the magnitude of the change in momentum of the snooker ball? A 0.020 kg m s–1  B 0.10 kg m s–1  C 0.14 kg m s–1  D 0.50 kg m s–1
Define acceleration.

An Olympic diver stands on a platform. His centre of gravity is 9.0 m above the water surface. He jumps with velocity 5.9 m s–1 at 60° to the horizontal. Air resistance is negligible. When he hits the water, his centre of gravity is 1.2 m above the water. Calculate the speed of the diver at the instant he hits the water.
(i) Describe and explain the variation of the viscous drag force acting on the diver in the water as he moves downwards.
(ii) The diver has a volume of 7.5 × 10^–2 m^3. The density of water is 1.0 × 10^3 kg m^–3. Show that the upthrust acting on the diver when he is entirely underwater is 740 N.

(iii) At a particular instant when the diver is entirely underwater his horizontal velocity is zero. The viscous drag force is 950 N vertically upwards and the diver’s mass is 78 kg. Determine the magnitude and direction of the acceleration of the diver.

A truck R of mass 9400 kg moves with constant acceleration in a straight line down a slope, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1. At point A the speed of the truck is 13 m s–1 and at point B the speed of the truck is 22 m s–1. A and B are a distance of 180 m apart. (i) Calculate the acceleration of the truck between A and B.
(ii) Determine the gain in kinetic energy of the truck between A and B.

A short time after passing point B truck R moves in a straight line on horizontal ground. The driver applies the brakes. Fig. 3.2 shows the variation with time of the momentum of the truck. (i) Define force.
(ii) Show that the average resultant force F acting on truck R between time t = 0 and t = 15 s is −1.2 × 10^4 N.

(iii) An identical truck S has the same initial momentum as truck R and experiences a constant force equal to F from (b)(ii). State and explain whether truck S will take more, less or the same time to come to rest as truck R.
A firework explodes into two fragments (m and 2m) with total KE E. What is speed of mass m fragment? A √(E/m)  B √(2E/m)  C √(2E/3m)  D √(4E/3m)
What is the definition of force? A mass × acceleration  B mass × velocity  C rate of change of momentum  D rate of transfer of energy
A boat moves at constant velocity v through water with drag force F. What is the power used? A ½Fv²  B Fv  C ½Fv  D 2Fv

A disc has diameter d and four equal forces F acting (two vertical, two horizontal). Which statement is correct? A equilibrium as resultant force = 0  B not equilibrium, resultant force 4F  C equilibrium as torque = 0  D not equilibrium, resultant torque 2Fd
Two equal-mass balls P and Q approach each other (P: 1.30 m s–1 right, Q: 0.50 m s–1 left). They collide elastically. Which diagram shows their motion after collision?

A car of mass 850 kg is travelling in a horizontal straight line. Two horizontal forces act: 1200 N and 1600 N in opposite directions. What is the magnitude of the acceleration of the car? A 0.47 m s–2  B 1.4 m s–2  C 1.9 m s–2  D 3.3 m s–2

An object of fixed mass starts at rest at point P and moves away with uniform acceleration. Which statement describes the resultant force acting on it when moving? A increases uniformly with time  B constant but not zero  C proportional to displacement  D zero
What is the definition of acceleration? A change in velocity per unit time  B rate of change of speed per unit time  C rate of change of velocity per unit time  D resultant force per unit mass

A car is accelerated by a constant resultant force of 300 N for 5.0 s. The variation with time of the velocity, in cm s–1, of the car is shown. What is the mass of the car? A 13 kg  B 1000 kg  C 1300 kg  D 10 000 kg

What is a statement of the principle of conservation of momentum for a system? A The total momentum and the total kinetic energy are always conserved. B The total momentum is conserved only in elastic collisions. C The total momentum is conserved provided that no external forces act. D The total momentum of each object in the system is the product of its mass and velocity.

Objects P (6.0 kg, 3.0 m s–1) and Q (2.0 kg, 4.2 m s–1 at 35°) collide and stick. What is the magnitude of the component of the final momentum in the original direction of P? A 9.6 kg m s–1 B 11 kg m s–1 C 13 kg m s–1 D 25 kg m s–1
An astronaut of mass m experiences weight mg at rest. What is the gravitational force on the astronaut when the spacecraft accelerates vertically upwards at 0.2g? A 1.2mg  B mg  C 0.8mg  D 0

A boat is crossing a river in which the water is moving at a speed of 4.0 m s–1 from left to right. In still water, the speed of the boat is 6.0 m s–1. The boat is directed at an angle θ to a line perpendicular to the river banks. The resultant velocity v of the boat is in a direction perpendicular to the river banks. What are the values of θ and v? A 42° , 4.5 m s–1  B 42° , 7.2 m s–1  C 48° , 4.5 m s–1  D 48° , 7.2 m s–1

A student walks at a constant speed for a distance of 50 m in a time of 40 s. The student rests for a time of 10 s and then walks back to the starting point at a constant speed in a time of 30 s. What is the distance–time graph for the motion of the student? (Options A–D diagrams.)

The time taken for an object to fall from rest through a certain distance on Mars is TM. The time taken for the same object to fall from rest through the same distance on Earth is TE. The acceleration of free fall on Mars is 3.71 m s–2. Assume that air resistance is negligible on both Earth and Mars. What is the ratio TM/TE ? A 0.378  B 0.615  C 1.63  D 2.64
What is the definition of acceleration? A rate of change of displacement  B rate of change of kinetic energy  C rate of change of momentum  D rate of change of velocity

On the Moon (g = 1.62 m s–2), a ball is thrown with vertical component 8.00 m s–1 and horizontal component 4.00 m s–1. What is the speed 9.00 s after being thrown? A 6.58  B 7.70  C 10.6  D 14.6 m s–1
A parachutist falls from a stationary balloon… v–t graph (P–Q–R–S) shown. Which graph best shows the variation with time of the acceleration of the parachutist? (Options A–D with a–t graphs.)

A projectile is fired from point P with velocity V at angle θ… lands at Q distance R after time T (g, no air resistance). Which equation is correct? A R = VT cos θ  B R = VT sin θ  C R = VT cos θ – ½gT2  D R = VT sin θ – ½gT2
A ball is kicked towards a vertical wall 9.0 m away at an angle of 38°; u_H = 9.5 m s–1. Air resistance is negligible. (a)(i) Show that the time to reach the wall is 0.95 s.
(a)(ii) Calculate the vertical component u_V of the initial velocity.
(a)(iii) Determine the impact height h above the ground when the ball reaches the wall.
(b) The speed just after impact is less than just before. State what this indicates about the nature of the collision with the wall.
In the following list, underline all quantities that are SI base quantities. charge    electric current    force    time

Under certain conditions, the distance s moved in a straight line by an object in time t is given by s = 1/2 a t^2 where a is the acceleration of the object. State two conditions under which the above expression applies to the motion of the object.

The variation with time t of the velocity v of a car that is moving in a straight line is shown. (i) Compare, qualitatively, the acceleration of the car at time t = 8.0 s and at time t = 14.0 s in terms of magnitude and direction.
(ii) Determine the magnitude of the acceleration of the car at time t = 4.0 s.
(iii) The car is at point X at time t = 0. Determine the magnitude of the displacement of the car from X at time t = 12.0 s.

A well has a depth of 36 m from ground level to the surface of the water. A student drops a stone from rest and times from release to hearing the splash. (a) Assume air resistance is negligible. Calculate the time taken for the stone to fall from ground level to the surface of the water.
(b) The time on the stop-watch is not equal to the time in (a). Suggest three possible reasons, other than the effect of air resistance, for this difference.
(c) Three repeated experiments give depths 54.4 m, 53.9 m and 54.1 m, but the true depth is 36.0 m. Explain why these results may be described as precise but not accurate.
The diagram shows two vectors, X and Y, drawn to scale. If X = Y – Z, which diagram represents the vector Z? (options A–D with vector diagrams)

Which equation, representing uniformly accelerated motion in a straight line, can be determined using only the definition of acceleration? A s = ut + ½at2  B s = ½(u + v)t  C v = u + at  D v2 = u2 + 2as

An object moves from rest with uniform velocity horizontally and uniform acceleration vertically. Which graph showing the variation with time of the displacement of the object from its initial position is correct? (options A–D with graphs)
A ball travels from X to Y around a semicircular track of radius 1.0 m. What is the displacement from X to Y? A 2.0 m  B 2.0 m due south  C 3.1 m  D 3.1 m due south
Identical rocks launched vertically at 12 m s–1 on Earth and on Mars; v–t graphs shown (air resistance negligible). What is the difference in maximum heights? A 12 m  B 15 m  C 19 m  D 24 m
A block slides distance x down a frictionless slope at angle θ. Which gives the final speed? A √(2gx sinθ)  B 2gx sinθ  C gx^2  D 2gx sinθ

One object moves directly from P to R. In a shorter time, a second object moves from P to Q to R. Which statement about the two objects is correct for the journey from P to R? A They have the same average speed.  B They have the same average velocity.  C They have the same displacement.  D They travel the same distance.

A ball is kicked so that it has an initial velocity of 12 m s–1 at an angle of 50° to horizontal ground (air resistance negligible). What is the maximum height above the ground that is reached by the ball? A 0.47 m  B 3.0 m  C 4.3 m  D 7.3 m

A boy throws a stone with a horizontal velocity of 10 m s–1 from the top of a building of height 8.0 m. Air resistance is negligible. How long does it take the stone to reach the ground? A 0.61 s B 0.80 s C 1.3 s D 1.6 s

Two identical balls are projected vertically upwards from ground level with the same initial velocity. Ball X is in a vacuum and ball Y is in air. Which statement about the motion is correct? A X reaches a greater maximum height and in a longer time than Y. B X reaches a greater maximum height and in a shorter time than Y. C Y reaches a greater maximum height and in a longer time than X. D Y reaches a greater maximum height and in a shorter time than X.

The graph shows velocity–time for a stone that falls from a bridge into a lake and sinks to the bottom. What can be deduced? A Terminal velocity was reached in air. B The acceleration in air was decreasing with increasing time. C The distance travelled in water was greater than the distance travelled in air. D The rate of change of velocity in air was constant.

The graph shows how the acceleration of an object moving in a straight line varies with time. The object starts from rest. Which graph shows the variation with time of the velocity of the object over the same time interval? (Options A–D as in paper.)
A stone falls vertically from rest. Air resistance is negligible. What is the speed of the stone when it has fallen through a distance of 0.40 m?  A 2.0 m s–1  B 2.8 m s–1  C 3.9 m s–1  D 7.8 m s–1

A ball is thrown horizontally off a tall building. The ground is horizontal. Air resistance is negligible. Which statement about the motion of the ball is correct?  A The acceleration of the ball is always at right angles to the path of the ball.  B The ball follows a circular path until it hits the ground.  C The ball has constant acceleration.  D The ball’s time in the air is proportional to the velocity at which the ball is thrown.
An object is projected at speed u and angle θ. Which statement does NOT describe the motion (air resistance negligible)? Options A–D as in paper.
A 200 km journey: first 90 km at 80 km h–1. What average speed is needed for the rest to make total time 2 h 0 min? A 110  B 120  C 122  D 126 km h–1
Toy parachute dropped; distance–time graph given. Which region shows terminal velocity?
Define acceleration.

A small aircraft is flying horizontally at a speed of 42 m s–1 at a height of 63 m above horizontal ground, as shown in Fig. 1.1. The aircraft drops a small parcel. The parcel is released from the aircraft at the instant shown in Fig. 1.1. Air resistance is negligible. (i) On Fig. 1.1, draw a line to show the path of the parcel as it falls from the aircraft to the ground.
(ii) Calculate the time taken from the instant of release to the instant the parcel reaches the ground.
(iii) Calculate the vertical component of the velocity of the parcel immediately before it reaches the ground.
(iv) Determine the speed at which the parcel reaches the ground.
(a) Define displacement from a point.

(b) An object is projected horizontally at a speed of 6.0 m s–1 from a slope at angle θ to the horizontal. Air resistance is negligible. The object lands on the slope 0.71 s later and stops without rolling or bouncing. (i) Determine the horizontal distance travelled by the object.
(b)(ii) Determine the vertical distance travelled by the object.
(b)(iii) Use your answers in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) to calculate θ.
(b)(iv) Determine the magnitude of the displacement of the object from its original position.
(b)(v) By considering energy, calculate the speed of the object just before it lands.
The velocity–time graph is shown. What is the displacement during the last 2 seconds of the motion? A 6 m  B 12 m  C 18 m  D 24 m
A ball hits a wall: before 8 m s–1 right, after 3 m s–1 left. What is the change in velocity of the ball during the collision? A 5 m s–1 left  B 5 m s–1 right  C 11 m s–1 left  D 11 m s–1 right

Which statement is not correct? A Acceleration from gradient of velocity–time graph.  B Acceleration is rate of change of velocity.  C Displacement from area under velocity–time graph.  D Velocity is the rate of change of distance.
In vacuum, a feather falls rest-to-bottom of a tube of length L in time T. How far has it fallen after time 0.50T? A 0.13L  B 0.25L  C 0.38L  D 0.50L
Car travels along a straight road. v–t graph shown; brakes applied from t = 1.0 s to 4.0 s. How far does the car travel while braking? A 21 m  B 45 m  C 67 m  D 83 m
An object moves with uniform acceleration a for time t from initial velocity u to final velocity v. Which equation describes the motion? A u = v – 2at  B u = v – at  C v = u + at  D v = u + 2at
Which calculation produces a vector quantity? A current × time  B final displacement – initial displacement  C work done/time  D ½ × mass × (speed)^2
A thermometer readable to ±0.5 °C measures a temperature rise from 40 °C to 100 °C. What is the percentage uncertainty in the temperature rise? A 0.5%  B 0.8%  C 1.3%  D 1.7%

The path of a golf ball is shown (air resistance ignored). Which row describes the horizontal and vertical components of velocity? (options A–D for horizontal constant/ deceleration and vertical acceleration behaviour)
An aircraft flies 17 000 km from London to Sydney in 21 h 40 min. What is the average speed? A 2.2 m s–1  B 2.2 × 10^7 μm s–1  C 2.2 × 10^11 nm s–1  D 2.2 × 10^6 mm s–1
A student throws a ball over a vertical wall. (a) Define velocity.

(b) The ball leaves the hand at height 1.2 m with initial speed 22 m s–1 at 40° to the horizontal; the wall is 36 m away; air resistance negligible. (i) Determine the time taken for the ball to reach the wall.
(ii) Calculate the vertical component u of the initial velocity of the ball.
(iii) The ball just goes over the wall. Calculate the height h of the wall.

A ball is kicked upwards at 45° to horizontal ground. Air resistance is negligible. During the flight, what is never zero? A the horizontal component of the ball’s acceleration  B the horizontal component of the ball’s velocity  C the vertical component of the ball’s momentum  D the vertical component of the ball’s velocity
A ball is projected and passes points Q, R, S, T with given heights and kinetic energies EQ, ER, ES, ET. Which difference in kinetic energies is smallest? A EQ–ES  B ES–ER  C ET–EQ  D ET–ER
A projectile is launched at 25° to the horizontal with horizontal velocity component 13 m s–1. What is the vertical velocity component on launch? A 5.5 m s–1  B 6.1 m s–1  C 12 m s–1  D 14 m s–1

A ball is released from rest at position X. At 1.0 s it bounces inelastically, reaching the top of its first bounce at 1.5 s. What is its total displacement from X at 1.5 s? A 1.25 m  B 3.75 m  C 5.00 m  D 6.25 m
A basketball is hit vertically downward at 2.4 m s–1 from a height of 0.90 m. Neglecting air resistance, what is its speed on impact? A 4.2 m s–1  B 4.8 m s–1  C 18 m s–1  D 23 m s–1
A projectile launched at 45° with kinetic energy E. Neglecting air resistance, what is KE at highest point? A 0.50E B 0.71E C 0.87E D E
An aircraft, initially stationary, must reach 85 km h–1 within 1.20 km. What is the minimum constant acceleration? A 0.23 m s–2 B 0.46 m s–2 C 3.0 m s–2 D 6.0 m s–2

An object is fired at 20 m s–1 at 45° from level ground (no air resistance). Which statement describes the speed from launch until just before landing? A decreases to >0 then increases to 20 m s–1  B decreases to >0 then increases to >20 m s–1  C decreases to 0 then increases to 20 m s–1  D decreases to 0 then increases to <20 m s–1

A uniform rigid beam of length 3.2 m is pivoted at its centre. Two children sit at the opposite ends of the beam. One child has a mass of 24 kg. The other has a mass of 36 kg. The heavier child causes one end of the beam to permanently rest on the ground, so that the beam makes an angle of 20° to the horizontal ground. What is the moment of the weight of the 24 kg child about the pivot? A 72 N m  B 130 N m  C 350 N m  D 380 N m

Mast and boom system: boom pivoted to mast; rope at 40° to horizontal exerts tension T; boom weight 200 N uniformly distributed; boom in equilibrium. What is the magnitude of T ? A 130 N  B 160 N  C 260 N  D 310 N

Full-fat milk: 1.000×10–3 m3 has mass 1.035 kg and contains 4.00% fat by volume. Density of fat-free milk is 1.040×103 kg m–3. What is the density of fat? A 1.25×102 kg m–3  B 9.15×102 kg m–3  C 9.28×102 kg m–3  D 1.16×103 kg m–3
Which expression for pressure is correct? A force per unit area  B mass per unit area  C mass per unit volume  D weight per unit volume

A wooden cylinder floats partially submerged in water. A force F is applied until it is just fully submerged. Which statement is not correct? A Some of the water gains gravitational potential energy.  B The cylinder loses gravitational potential energy.  C Work is done by force F on the cylinder.  D Work is done by the upthrust on the cylinder.
A force F is applied at 45° to a door handle at distance d from the pivot. What is the moment of the force about the pivot? A Fd/2  B Fd  C 2Fd  D √2Fd
A couple consists of two forces of magnitude F acting in opposite directions in the same plane with perpendicular separation d. What is the torque of the couple? A Fd/2  B F/d  C Fd  D 2Fd

Ball weight 0.15 N suspended by a light string; string deflected 30° by horizontal air flow; ball in equilibrium. What is the force on the ball from the air flow? A 0.075 N  B 0.087 N  C 0.26 N  D 0.30 N

Two solid cylinders X and Y (same volume) are fully submerged. Density of Y is twice that of X. Which statement is correct? A Force on top of X is greater than on top of Y. B Pressure difference between top and bottom is the same for X and Y. C Upthrust on X equals upthrust on Y. D Weight of X equals weight of Y.
In an experiment, a metal ball is dropped into a viscous liquid… Which two changes separately affect the terminal velocity of the ball? A 1 and 2  B 1 and 3  C 2 and 4  D 3 and 4
A minimum torque of 20 N m must be applied to the lid of a jar (radius 4.0 cm)… What is the minimum force F that must act on each side of the lid? A 2.5 N  B 5.0 N  C 250 N  D 500 N
A uniform bar length L and weight W rests on two supports X and Y… RX at L/6, RY at other end… bar in equilibrium. What is the ratio R_X / R_Y ? A 2/3  B 3/2  C 5/3  D 5/2

Two opposite rockets on a rod about a pivot; weight W; pivot force R equals and opposite to W; each rocket exerts F at distance d in opposite directions. Which statement is correct? A The firework is in equilibrium because resultant force is zero.  B … resultant torque is zero.  C Not in equilibrium because resultant force not zero.  D Not in equilibrium because resultant torque not zero.
Object weight W immersed in water (reading P) and oil (reading Q) on a newton meter. What is density(oil)/density(water)? A (W−P)/(Q−P)  B (Q−P)/(W−P)  C (W−P)/(W−Q)  D (W−Q)/(W−P)
(a) State the conditions for a system to be in equilibrium.
(b)(i) An airship has upthrust 93 000 N in air of density 1.2 kg m–3. Calculate the volume of air displaced.
(b)(ii) When fully loaded, weight exceeds upthrust. Fans provide total vertical thrust 3.0 × 10^3 N upwards to maintain horizontal flight. Calculate the mass of the airship.
(c) A fan exerts 2800 N thrust by accelerating 64 kg of air in 0.50 s (initially stationary). (i) Calculate the change in momentum Δp of the air.
(c)(ii) Determine the speed of the air as it leaves the fan.
(c)(iii) Calculate the total kinetic energy of this air due to its movement through the fan.

A high-altitude balloon is stationary in still air. A solid sphere is suspended from the balloon by a string. The volume of the balloon is 7.5 m^3. The total weight of the balloon, string and sphere is 65 N. The upthrust acting on the string and sphere is negligible. (a) Calculate the density of the air surrounding the balloon.
(b) The string breaks, releasing the sphere. (i) State the magnitude of the acceleration of the sphere immediately after the string breaks.
(ii) State and explain the variation, if any, in the magnitude of the acceleration of the sphere when it is moving downwards before it reaches terminal (constant) velocity.
(c) The sphere has a mass of 4.0 kg. Calculate the total resistive force acting on the sphere at the instant when its acceleration is 1.9 m s–2.

A hot-air balloon floats just above the ground, held by a vertical rope (Fig. 2.1). The balloon has weight W = 3.39 × 10^4 N, rope tension T = 4.00 × 10^2 N. Upthrust U acts on the balloon. Air density is 1.23 kg m–3. (a)(i) On Fig. 2.1, draw labelled arrows to show the directions of the three forces acting on the balloon.
(a)(ii) Calculate the volume, to three significant figures, of the balloon.
(a)(iii) The balloon is released from the rope. Calculate the initial acceleration of the balloon.

(b) The balloon is stationary at a height of 500 m. A tennis ball is released from rest and falls vertically from the balloon. A passenger uses v^2 = u^2 + 2as to predict ≈100 m s–1 at impact. Explain why the actual speed will be much lower when it hits the ground.
(c) Before release, the rope strain is 2.4 × 10^–5; rope unstretched length 2.5 m; obeys Hooke’s law. (i) Show that the extension is 6.0 × 10^–5 m.
(c)(ii) Calculate the elastic potential energy EP of the rope.

(c)(iii) The rope is replaced by a new one (same original length and cross-sectional area), same tension, also obeys Hooke’s law. The new rope’s material has a lower Young modulus. State and explain the effect on the elastic potential energy of the rope.
A sphere floats in equilibrium on sea water of density 1050 kg m–3; 21% of its volume is below the surface. (a) Calculate the density of the sphere.
(b) The sphere is held fully below the surface and then released. (i) Calculate the initial acceleration of the sphere.
(b)(ii) The sphere accelerates upwards but remains entirely below the surface. State and explain what happens to the acceleration of the sphere as its velocity begins to increase.
(a) State what is meant by the centre of gravity of an object.

(b) A pivoted horizontal beam carries two blocks (weights 54 N and 2.4 N at given distances). A string at 30° supports the right end and the beam is in equilibrium. (i) By taking moments about the pivot, calculate the tension T in the string.
(b)(ii) The string is cut so the beam is no longer in equilibrium. Calculate the magnitude of the resultant moment about the pivot immediately after the cut.

(c) A 2.4 N block is projected from height 1.8 m; at point X its speed is 3.4 m s–1 and it lands at Y. Air resistance negligible. (i) Calculate the decrease in gravitational potential energy from X to Y.
(c)(ii) Use your answer to (c)(i) and conservation of energy to determine the kinetic energy at Y.
(c)(iii) State the variation, if any, in the direction of the acceleration of the block as it moves from X to Y.
(c)(iv) On provided axes, sketch the variation of the magnitude of the horizontal component of velocity with time from t_X to t_Y (no numerical values required).

A beaker in air contains a liquid. The base of the beaker is in contact with the liquid and has area A, as shown in Fig. 4.1. The liquid has density ρ and fills the beaker to a depth h. (a) By using the definitions of pressure and density, show that p = ρgh, where p is the pressure due to the liquid that is exerted on the base of the beaker and g is the acceleration of free fall.
(b) Suggest why the equation in (a) does not give the total pressure on the base of the beaker.
(c) Fig. 4.2 shows the variation of the total pressure inside the liquid with depth x below the surface. Determine the density of the liquid.

A solid cylinder is held stationary by a wire so that the base of the cylinder is level with the surface of the liquid, as shown in Fig. 4.3. The cylinder has length 4.0 × 10–2 m and cross-sectional area 3.7 × 10–4 m2. The tension in the wire is 0.53 N. The cylinder is now lowered and then held stationary by the wire so that the top of the cylinder is level with the surface of the liquid. Calculate the new tension in the wire.
(a)(i) Show that the vertical component of the tension in the string is 2.4 N.
(a)(ii) By taking moments about the hinge, determine the weight W of the beam.
(a)(iii) Calculate the horizontal component of the force exerted on the beam by the hinge.
(b) The spring obeys Hooke’s law and has an elastic potential energy of 0.32 J. Calculate the compression of the spring.
(c)(i) Calculate the decrease in the gravitational potential energy of the block for its movement from A to B.
(c)(ii) Use your answer in (c)(i) and conservation of energy to determine the speed of the block at point A.
(c)(iii) By reference to the force on the block, explain why the horizontal component of the velocity of the block remains constant as it moves from A to B.

(c)(iv) On Fig. 2.3, sketch a graph to show the variation of the magnitude of the vertical component v_Y of the velocity of the block with time t from t = t_A to t = t_B. Numerical values of v_Y are not required.

What is not a requirement for two forces to act as a couple? A The two forces act in opposite directions.  B The two forces act through the same point.  C The two forces combine to produce zero resultant force.  D The two forces have equal magnitude.
A uniform metre rule is pivoted at the 34.0 cm mark and balances when a 64 g mass is hung from the 4.0 cm mark. What is the mass of the metre rule? A 38 g  B 44 g  C 120 g  D 136 g

A volume of 1.5 m3 of water (1000 kg m–3) is mixed with 0.50 m3 of alcohol (800 kg m–3). The volume of the mixture is 2.0 m3. What is the density of the mixture? A 850 kg m–3  B 900 kg m–3  C 940 kg m–3  D 950 kg m–3

An object is falling at a constant speed through a viscous liquid. FU is the upthrust on the object due to the liquid. WL is the weight of the liquid displaced. WO is the weight of the object. Which equation must be correct? A FU = WL  B FU = WO – WL  C FU = WO  D FU = WO + WL
A stone sinks in water. What is a possible value for the density of the stone? A 8 × 10^2 kg m–3  B 2 × 10^3 kg m–3  C 8 × 10^3 N m–3  D 2 × 10^4 N m–3

A submarine of total mass 3200 kg is at rest underwater. The total mass is suddenly decreased by 200 kg by pumping water out horizontally in a negligible time. Upthrust is unchanged. What is the initial upwards acceleration of the submarine? A 0.613 m s–2  B 0.654 m s–2  C 9.81 m s–2  D 10.5 m s–2
A rod is pivoted at O. A force F is applied at W. What is the moment of the force F about O? A F × distance OX  B F × distance OY  C F × distance WO  D F × distance WX
A uniform rod XY of weight 10.0 N is hinged at X. It is held horizontal by a force F at Y at 30° to the horizontal. What is F? A 5.0 N  B 8.7 N  C 10 N  D 20 N
Two solid cubes X and Y are the same density. Cube X has twice the mass of cube Y. X has side x; Y has side y. What is x/y? A 1.26  B 1.41  C 2.00  D 8.00

A U-shaped tube contains liquid of density 2000 kg m–3 with level difference (6.0 cm vs 10.0 cm) between P and Q. What is the pressure difference due to the liquid between P and Q? A 780 Pa  B 1200 Pa  C 1600 Pa  D 2000 Pa

The driver of a car applies two parallel forces of 15 N to a 0.40 m diameter steering wheel at 65° as shown. What is the torque exerted on the steering wheel? A 1.3 N m  B 2.5 N m  C 2.7 N m  D 5.4 N m

A farmer lifts the corner of a large water tank using a metal rod as a lever. The vertical force from the farmer is constant and applied at the end of the rod. Which change must increase the upward force on the water tank? A longer rod + pivot closer to tank  B longer rod + pivot further  C shorter rod + pivot closer  D shorter rod + pivot further

A ball of weight W hangs in equilibrium from a string at angle θ to the vertical; tension is T. A horizontal force P from a rod holds the ball away from the wall. Which relationship between T, P and W is correct? A P = T cosθ and W = T sinθ  B T = P + W  C T^2 = P^2 + W^2  D W = P tanθ and W = T cosθ
Which expression for pressure is correct? A force per unit area  B force per unit volume  C mass per unit area  D mass per unit volume
A ball has mass 0.50 kg and volume 1.3 × 10–3 m3 and floats on water (ρ = 1.0 × 10^3 kg m–3). What percentage of the ball’s volume is above the surface? A 3.9%  B 38%  C 62%  D 96%

Four equal cuboids are immersed at the same depth in water; materials have densities 4ρ, 2ρ, ρ and 0.5ρ. Which statement is correct? A Upthrust on each is the same. B Upthrust on W is twice that on X. C Upthrust on X is twice that on W. D Upthrust on Y is zero.
Which statement correctly describes a couple? A pair of forces that act in the same direction / on centre of gravity / produce resultant force / produce rotation only. A B C D

A uniform 0.60 m beam of mass 1.4 kg is pivoted at P, 0.20 m from one end. Loads of 3.0 kg and 6.0 kg hang at 0.35 m and 0.15 m from P. What torque must be applied to maintain equilibrium? A 0.010 N m B 0.10 N m C 0.29 N m D 2.8 N m
Three rigid objects P, Q, R under different force combinations. Which objects are in equilibrium? A P and Q B P and R C Q and R D none
Two immiscible liquids P and Q are in equilibrium in a U-tube. Three equal distances x are marked. What is the ratio density of Q / density of P ? A 1/2 B 2/3 C 3/2 D 2

Which single condition must apply for an object to be in equilibrium?  A The object has a constant non-zero acceleration.  B The object is stationary.  C There are no forces acting on the object.  D The resultant force acting on the object is zero.

A kite is in equilibrium at the end of a string. The kite has three forces acting on it: the weight W, the tension T in the string, and the force F from the wind. Which vector diagram represents the forces acting on the kite? (Options A–D as in paper.)
Four forces act about a point P, as shown. The forces act in the same plane and produce no resultant moment about point P. What is the length XY?  A 6.9 m  B 12 m  C 14 m  D 24 m

A rectangular block of lead of density 1.13 × 10^4 kg m–3 has sides of length 12.0 cm, 15.0 cm and 10.0 cm. What is the maximum pressure the block can exert when resting on a table?  A 1.13 kPa  B 1.70 kPa  C 11.1 kPa  D 16.6 kPa
Less-dense-than-water sphere released from depth in uniform-density water. How do upthrust and resultant force magnitudes change as it rises? Options A–D.

Which diagram of equal forces on a metre rule gives a couple and zero resultant force?

Initially h = 0.10 m and x = 0.40 m and the system is in equilibrium. (i) Use the principle of moments to show that the upthrust U on the cylinder is 1.4 N.

The drag force FD acting on a sphere falling through a liquid is given by FD = 6πηr v, where r is the radius of the sphere, v is the speed of the sphere in the liquid and η is the viscosity. (a) Show that the SI base units of viscosity are kg m–1 s–1.

(b) The sphere has a radius of 3.0 cm and is falling vertically downwards at a terminal velocity of 2.0 m s–1 through the liquid. The drag force acting on the sphere is 0.096 N. Calculate the viscosity of the liquid.
(c) The sphere is shown in Fig. 1.1. On Fig. 1.1, draw and label arrows to represent the directions of the three forces acting on the sphere as it falls at terminal velocity through the liquid.
(d)(i) The density of the liquid is 920 kg m–3. Show that the upthrust acting on the sphere is 1.0 N.
(d)(ii) Calculate the mass of the sphere.

A floating sphere (weight 5.00 N) supports a probe and string (combined 2.00 N). Seawater density 1.03 × 10^3 kg m–3. Upthrust on probe/string negligible. What is the volume of the sphere below the sea surface? A 1.98×10–4  B 2.97×10–4  C 4.95×10–4  D 6.93×10–4 m^3

A borehole 2000 m deep contains oil and water. Pressure at bottom = 17.5 MPa. Density oil = 830 kg m–3, density water = 1000 kg m–3. What is depth x of oil? A 907 m  B 1000 m  C 1090 m  D 1270 m
A rod pivoted at one end has weight causing moment M. As the angle θ increases from 0° to 180°, which graph shows variation of M with θ?

A ball falls at constant speed through a liquid, acted upon by weight, drag, and upthrust. Which statement is correct? A drag force increases with depth  B drag = upthrust + weight  C upthrust is constant with depth  D weight > drag + upthrust

An electric car travels 80 km at 70 km h–1 using energy E. Total resistive force ∝ (speed)²; motor 100% efficient. How much energy is used for 80 km at 60 km h–1? A 0.73E  B 0.86E  C 1.2E  D 1.4E

Assume Hooke’s law for all compressions. On the provided axes, sketch the variation with x of Δh. Numerical values are not required.

A variable force supplies constant power to a train. Which graph shows force F versus velocity v? (A, B, C, D)

Ball of mass m thrown to height h with initial speed v (air resistance negligible). Total work done by gravity from P to Q? A 0  B ½mv²  C mgh  D 2mgh
