An electromagnetic wave in free space has a frequency of 3.0 × 10^16 Hz. Which row gives the principal region of this wave and an example of an electromagnetic wave with a lower frequency?  A infrared, visible light  B infrared, X-rays  C ultraviolet, visible light  D ultraviolet, X-rays

A source of sound emits waves of a constant frequency. The source moves at a constant speed in a straight line relative to a stationary observer. Which velocity of the source gives the smallest observed frequency?  A 5 m s–1 away from observer  B 10 m s–1 away from observer  C 15 m s–1 towards observer  D 20 m s–1 towards observer

What could describe the time-base of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO)?  A the frequency per division on the screen  B the number of divisions on the screen per unit frequency  C the number of divisions on the screen per unit time  D the time per division on the screen

What happens when two waves superpose at a point?  A Their amplitudes are added together.  B Their displacements are added together.  C Their frequencies are added together.  D Their velocities are added together.

An electromagnetic wave is diffracted as it passes through a single slit. The width of the slit is larger than the wavelength of the wave. Which change will decrease the amount of diffraction of the wave?  A Decrease the frequency of the wave.  B Decrease the time period of the wave.  C Decrease the width of the slit.  D Increase the wavelength of the wave.

The diagram shows visible light incident normally on a diffraction grating. A pattern of intensity maxima forms on the screen. A line connecting the centre of the fourth order intensity maximum with the centre of the diffraction grating forms an angle of 53° with the centre line. The grating has a line spacing of 2.7 × 10–6 m. What is the wavelength of the incident light?  A 4.1 × 10–7 m  B 5.4 × 10–7 m  C 1.6 × 10–6 m  D 2.2 × 10–6 m
Progressive wave displacement vs distance graph; period 91 ms. What can be determined? Options on velocity/frequency/wavelength and longitudinal/transverse.
Which EM group is ordered from shortest to longest wavelength? Options A–D.
A wave has frequency 5 GHz. What is its period? A 200 ps  B 2 ns  C 20 ns  D 20 000 μs
Which statements must be correct for two waves to be coherent? 1 same f, 2 same amplitude, 3 constant phase difference. Options A–D.
Two waves P and Q same amplitude meet in phase at X with resultant intensity I. If amplitude of P doubles, what is new intensity at X (in terms of I)? A 0.44I  B 1.5I  C 2.3I  D 3.0I
Why can radio waves be polarised but sound waves cannot? Options on transverse vs longitudinal, etc.
Light (λ) on a grating width w with total N lines; 2nd order at angle θ. What is N? Options A–D in terms of λ, θ, w.

(a)(i) A stationary wave is formed on a string XY of length 0.48 m (Fig. 5.1). The wave speed on the string is 1400 m s–1. On Fig. 5.1, draw a cross (×) at one position that is a node and another cross at one position that is an antinode. Label the node N and the antinode A.
(a)(ii) Show that the wavelength of the wave produced is 0.32 m. Explain your reasoning.
(a)(iii) Calculate the frequency of the wave.

(b)(i) A source of sound of frequency 780 Hz is on a rotating platform. The source speed is 39 m s–1. The speed of sound in air is 320 m s–1. Calculate the maximum frequency detected by a distant observer.

(b)(ii) At time t = 0, the observer detects the sound emitted when the source is at the position shown in Fig. 5.2. On Fig. 5.3, sketch the variation with time t of the detected frequency f for one complete rotation. Calculations are not required.
(a) With reference to the direction of transfer of energy, compare the oscillations of transverse and longitudinal progressive waves.

(b) A pipe is open at one end and closed at the other with a piston that is 4.5 × 10^–2 m from the open end. A loudspeaker near the open end emits a single-frequency sound; a stationary wave is formed as in Fig. 4.1. (i) On Fig. 4.1, draw a letter A at the position of an antinode.
(b)(ii) The speed of sound in air is 340 m s–1. Determine the frequency of the sound wave.

(b)(iii) The piston is moved to the left and the loudspeaker frequency is changed so a stationary wave with the same number of antinodes is formed. State and explain the change that is made to the frequency of the sound wave.

Two coherent sources X and Y of microwaves of frequency 2.5 × 10^10 Hz are a distance of 0.18 m apart in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 6.1. The detector moves along line PQ, parallel to XY and 2.3 m away. Point O on PQ is equidistant from X and Y. Point A on PQ is where the intensity is greatest.

(a)(i) Explain why the position of greatest intensity is not at point O.
(ii) On Fig. 6.1, draw a cross (×) to show the position on PQ of the intensity minimum that is closest to O. Label this point B.
(b)(i) Show that the wavelength of the microwaves is 0.012 m.
(b)(ii) For point A on PQ, determine the difference in the distances Δx travelled by the microwaves from X and from Y.
(b)(iii) Use the formula for double-slit interference of light to calculate the distance between adjacent intensity maxima on line PQ.
A progressive transverse wave travelling from left to right is shown at an instant in time in Fig. 4.1. R and T are points on the wave. (a) State the phase difference between the points R and T.
(b) On Fig. 4.1, draw an arrow at point T to show the direction of movement of point T at the instant shown.
The horizontal distance between R and T is 0.62 cm, as shown in Fig. 4.2. The speed of the wave is 0.27 m s–1. Calculate the frequency of the wave.

The wave is a water wave produced by a dipper S1 attached to a vibrator in a ripple tank. An identical dipper S2 is attached to the same vibrator. The two dippers produce an interference pattern on the water in the tank, as shown in Fig. 4.3. The wave crests from each source are represented by solid lines and the wave troughs by dashed lines. At point P in Fig. 4.3, the wave from S1 has the same amplitude A as the wave from S2. Describe and explain the amplitude of the resultant wave at point P.
Water waves pass through an 8 m wide harbour gap and diffract. For which wavelength is diffraction greatest? A 1 m  B 2 m  C 4 m  D 8 m
An oscilloscope trace of a wave is shown. The y-gain is 3.5 mV cm–1. What is the amplitude? A 0.57 mV  B 3.5 mV  C 7.0 mV  D 14 mV

A transverse progressive wave on a string has wavelength 12 cm and amplitude 1.5 cm. Its speed is 48 cm s–1. What distance does a point on the string travel in 2.0 s? A 12 cm  B 24 cm  C 48 cm  D 96 cm

An ambulance with siren frequency f travels towards, passes, and then away from a stationary observer. Which describes the frequency detected as it passes the observer? A equal to f and decreasing  B equal to f and increasing  C greater than f and constant  D less than f and constant
An electromagnetic wave has wavelength 138 pm in vacuum. To which region does it belong? A radio  B microwave  C visible light  D X-ray

Microwaves are vertically polarised. With the metal grille’s transmission axis vertical, the voltmeter reads 3.50 V (intensity ∝ reading). When rotated, the reading is 2.20 V. What is the rotation angle θ? A 37.5°  B 39.0°  C 51.0°  D 52.5°

Interference fringes of separation x are observed on a screen 1.00 m from a double slit using yellow light of wavelength 600 nm. At what distance from the slits would fringes of the same separation x be observed using blue light of wavelength 400 nm?
A stationary sound wave forms in a tube open at both ends. The stationary wave has three nodes. How many antinodes does it have?
A diffraction grating with N lines per metre is used for various wavelengths λ. A graph of sinθ versus λ for the n-th order is considered. What is the gradient of the graph?
A guitar string is plucked. Which statement describes the resulting waves in the string and in the air?
Polarisation is associated with certain waves. Which waves cannot be polarised?

A stationary sound wave is set up between a loudspeaker and a wall. A microphone on a CRO moves along the line between them: the CRO amplitude is maximum at X, then minimum, then maximum at Y. The distance X–Y is 33 cm and the speed of sound is 330 m s–1. Which diagram could represent the CRO trace at X (time-base 0.50 ms cm–1 shown on each option)?

A loudspeaker plays music in a room. The door is open with width 0.80 m. Sound waves of many frequencies pass through and diffract (speed in air is 340 m s–1). Which frequency diffracts the most as it passes through the doorway?

A man stands stationary in front of a swing. A child sits and swings, blowing a whistle of constant frequency. The man observes the frequency when the swing is at positions X, Y and Z. When will the man hear the highest frequency?

Light of a single frequency is incident normally on a diffraction grating. An interference pattern of bright and dark fringes forms on the semicircular screen shown in Fig. 6.1. The light has wavelength 520 nm. The separation of the lines in the grating is 3.8 × 10–6 m. (a) Determine the total number of bright fringes formed on the screen.
(b) The light is replaced with red light of a single frequency. (i) State whether the frequency of the red light is greater than, less than or the same as the frequency of the original light.
(ii) State and explain the effect of this change on the number of bright fringes formed on the screen. A calculation is not required.
An electromagnetic wave is travelling through a vacuum. What could be the wavelength and period of the electromagnetic wave? (table of options A–D in the paper)

Light of frequency 6.7 × 10^14 Hz in a vacuum is incident normally on a diffraction grating that contains 4.0 × 10^5 lines m–1. What is the angle between the adjacent second and third order intensity maxima?

The siren of a moving police car emits a sound wave with a frequency of 440 Hz. A stationary observer hears 494 Hz. The speed of sound is 340 m s–1. What could be the speed and the direction of movement of the car? (options A–D in the paper)

The diagram shows the shape at one instant of part of a stretched string as a wave travels left→right. What are the directions of the velocities of points 1, 2 and 3 at this instant? (options A–D in the paper)
Which wave cannot be a longitudinal wave? A a diffracted wave  B a polarised wave  C a reflected wave  D a stationary wave

A plane polarised wave has amplitude A. The wave is incident normally on a polarising filter. The transmission axis of the filter is at angle θ to the plane of polarisation of the incident wave. What is the amplitude of the wave that emerges from the filter? (options given in the paper)

A plane wave of amplitude A falls normally on a surface of area S; the energy per unit time reaching it is E. The amplitude is increased to 2A and the area is reduced to S/2. How much energy per unit time reaches the smaller surface? A 4E  B 2E  C E  D E/2
(a)(i) A microphone and CRO analyse a 5000 Hz sound wave (trace shown). Determine the time-base setting, in s cm–1, of the CRO.
(a)(ii) The sound intensity increases from I to 3I (frequency unchanged). Assuming CRO trace amplitude ∝ sound amplitude, sketch the new CRO trace on the figure provided.
(b)(i) Double-slit interference with laser light: explain why a bright fringe is produced at the central point P on the screen.
(b)(ii) Wavelength λ = 630 nm; slit separation = 3.6 × 10⁻⁴ m; adjacent bright-fringe spacing = 4.0 × 10⁻³ m; screen distance = D. Calculate D.
(c) With D and slit separation fixed, sketch the graph of bright-fringe spacing x versus wavelength λ from 400 nm to 700 nm (no numerical values required).

A receiving aerial behind a mountain detects radio waves (λ = 1.5 km) but not microwaves (λ = 1.5 cm). Why? A radio coherent but microwave not  B radio diffracts round mountain but microwave does not  C radio reflected but microwave not  D radio travels at c but microwave does not
Which statement about longitudinal and transverse waves is not correct? A Both can be polarised. B Both can form stationary waves. C Both can transfer energy as progressive waves. D Both obey v = fλ.

An observer hears a sound wave from a moving source; observed frequency is less than emitted. What could be the reason? A source moving away  B source moving towards  C speed of sound decreases due to motion  D speed of sound increases due to motion
What is the approximate frequency range of electromagnetic radiation visible to the human eye? A (430–750) kHz  B (430–750) MHz  C (430–750) GHz  D (430–750) THz

Vertically polarised light passes a polarising filter. The filter is rotated: first 30° (giving intensity I30), then another 30°. What is the new transmitted intensity? A 0.25 I30  B 0.33 I30  C 0.75 I30  D 0.87 I30

Two water-surface particles P and Q are a fixed horizontal distance apart in a progressive wave. At t = 0 the wave is as shown. Which graph best represents the variation with time of their phase difference φ?
(a) By reference to the direction of propagation of energy, state what is meant by a transverse wave.
(b) A space telescope is designed to detect electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths in the range 12 μm to 28 μm. State the region of the electromagnetic spectrum for this radiation.

(c) A detector on another space telescope detects an electromagnetic wave. The signal from the detector is transmitted to Earth and displayed on an oscilloscope, as shown in Fig. 5.1. The time-base setting is 5.0 × 10^–15 s cm^–1 and the displayed signal frequency equals the wave frequency. Calculate the wavelength of the detected wave.

A stationary loudspeaker emits sound of constant frequency. A microphone is placed near to the loudspeaker and connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO). The trace on the screen of the CRO is shown in Fig. 5.1. The time-base of the CRO is set to 5.0 × 10–4 s cm–1. (a) The speed of the sound emitted by the loudspeaker is 330 m s–1. Determine the wavelength of the sound.

(b) The loudspeaker now moves in a straight line while emitting the same sound of constant frequency. The period of the trace on the CRO increases continuously. Describe the motion of the loudspeaker.

In a double-slit experiment using a laser, the fringes on the screen are very close together. Which quantity should be decreased to increase fringe separation? A the distance p from laser to double slit  B the distance q from double slit to screen  C the separation r of the slits  D the wavelength of the light
Blue whale emits sound 10–40 Hz. Speed of sound in seawater ≈ 1.5 km/s. What is wavelength range? A 6.7 mm–27 mm  B 3.8 cm–15 cm  C 6.7 m–27 m  D 38 m–150 m
A sound wave of frequency 2.5 kHz displayed on CRO. Trace shows 1 cm per cycle. What is the time-base setting? A 0.1 ms cm–1  B 0.4 ms cm–1  C 0.1 s cm–1  D 0.4 s cm–1
A source of sound moves towards an observer. What does the observer detect? A decreased frequency  B no change in frequency  C decreased wavelength  D no change in wavelength
Which type of waves cannot be polarised? A radio  B sound  C ultraviolet  D X-rays
A light beam of power P, cross-sectional area A, amplitude X. Beam is changed to amplitude 4X and area A/3. What is new power? A 1.3P  B 5.3P  C 12P  D 48P
Two loudspeakers produce a stationary sound wave. Microphone moves 2.0 m from 1st to 5th maximum (5 maxima). What is wavelength? A 0.40 m  B 0.50 m  C 0.80 m  D 1.0 m
Two wave sources emit coherent waves. Which condition must be correct? A emitted in phase  B opposite directions  C constant phase difference  D same amplitude
Which row correctly identifies the properties of all electromagnetic waves? (transverse/longitudinal/can travel in free space)
What is the approximate range of wavelengths in free space for infrared radiation? A 100 nm–400 nm  B 300 μm–30 cm  C 400–700 nm  D 800 nm–1000 μm

A car travels at constant speed sounding its horn. Person P is ahead, person Q behind. Which statements are correct? 1. P hears increasing frequency. 2. Q hears decreasing frequency. 3. Q always hears higher frequency than P.
A progressive wave of frequency 300 Hz travels at 600 m/s. What is the phase difference between two points 0.50 m apart? A 45°  B 90°  C 180°  D 360°
A polarised beam of light (intensity I) passes a polarising filter. After rotation θ, transmitted intensity = 0.75I. What is θ? A 30° B 42° C 49° D 60°
Light waves from two sources produce interference fringes. What condition is necessary? A waves must be polarised  B not polarised  C coherent  D equal amplitudes
A water wave passes a gap. Wavelength ≪ gap. Which changes increase diffraction? A λ↓ gap↓  B λ↓ gap↑  C λ↑ gap↓  D λ↑ gap↑
Light λ=567 nm incident on diffraction grating (400 lines/mm). What is the angle between 2nd and 3rd order maxima? A 13.1°  B 13.9°  C 15.9°  D 27.0°

Which statement concerning a stationary wave is correct? A All the particles between two adjacent nodes oscillate in phase.  B The amplitude of the stationary wave is equal to the amplitude of one of the waves creating it.  C The wavelength of the stationary wave is equal to the separation of two adjacent nodes.  D There is no displacement of a particle at an antinode at any time.

Stationary sound waves can be formed in pipes. One type is closed at one end and open at the other. Another type is open at both ends. Which pipe can form a stationary sound wave with the lowest frequency? (Options A–D pipe diagrams with L and 2L.)
Water waves in a ripple tank pass through a small gap. Which diagram shows the waves after they have passed through the gap? (Options A–D.)

Light of a single wavelength is incident normally on a double slit. The slit separation a can be varied. Screen is at fixed distance and parallel to the slits. Which graph best shows the variation of the separation x of bright fringes with slit separation a? (Options A–D graphs.)
A diffraction grating with slit spacing 1.15 × 10–6 m gives an angle between the first-order diffraction maxima of 60.0°. What is the wavelength of the light? A 288 nm  B 498 nm  C 575 nm  D 996 nm
What can explain how stationary waves are formed from progressive waves? A diffraction  B polarisation  C superposition  D Doppler effect
A 2.0 m pipe open at one end and closed at the other has a stationary sound wave with four nodes and four antinodes within its length. What is the wavelength? A 0.57 m  B 1.1 m  C 1.3 m  D 1.6 m
Coherent light (fixed wavelength) at normal incidence on a double slit forms fringes on a parallel screen at fixed distance. Slit separation a is varied. Which graph shows fringe spacing x versus a?

A stationary wave is formed on a string between two fixed points. Which statement is correct? A At certain times, the string between two nodes is horizontal with all points having zero displacement.  B Each point between two antinodes has the same amplitude.  C The number of nodes equals the number of antinodes.  D Two adjacent antinodes oscillate in phase.

Two point sources R and S emit light of wavelength λ to a distant screen. At point P the intensity is zero. What could explain zero intensity at P? A 180° out of phase and path difference λ/2  B In phase and path difference λ  C 90° out of phase and path difference λ  D In phase and path difference λ/2
(a)(i) Two coherent sources A and B emit in phase with wavelength λ (Fig. 5.1). On Fig. 5.1, mark with a cross (×) the position of an interference maximum Y.
(a)(ii) On Fig. 5.1, mark with a cross (×) the position of an interference minimum Z.
(b)(i) In air, λ = 2.9 × 10^–5 m. An interference pattern is detected along a line a perpendicular distance 140 m from AB; adjacent maxima spacing is 1.2 cm. Calculate the separation a of A and B.
(b)(ii) State the principal region of the electromagnetic spectrum to which these waves belong.
(a) State the principle of superposition.

(b) Coherent light is incident on two identical slits X and Y; the screen is 1.9 m away. Slit separation is 0.65 mm. The distance between adjacent bright fringes is 1.7 mm (Fig. 4.1). Calculate the wavelength λ of the light.

(c) At a point between adjacent bright fringes, the waves from X and Y meet. Fig. 4.2 shows displacement–time for each wave at that point. Statement 1: “The phase difference is 90°.” Statement 2: “The amplitude of the resultant wave is zero.” (i) Explain how statement 1 is correct.
(c)(ii) State and explain whether statement 2 is correct.
(d) The width of each slit is decreased by the same amount (slit separation unchanged). Describe and explain the effect, if any, on the appearance of the interference pattern.

A string between fixed points X and Y shows a stationary wave. Solid curve is maximum displacement at time t0; dashed curve is the other maximum displacement; central dashed line is mean position. Point S is above P; point T is below Q. Which statement is correct? A Shortly after t0, point R will be displaced.  B Shortly after t0, S and T move in opposite directions.  C Distance PQ is one wavelength.  D Two moving points equal distances from R vibrate in phase.
The variation with distance x of intensity I along a stationary sound wave in air is shown. The speed of sound is 340 m s–1. What is the frequency? A 1700 Hz  B 2300 Hz  C 3400 Hz  D 6800 Hz
Waves in a ripple tank pass through a gap of width w with some diffraction. The wavelength is then doubled. What new gap width produces the same diffraction as before? A 0.5w  B w  C 2w  D 4w

Two coherent electromagnetic waves travel in a vacuum and meet at a point with different intensities. Which statement is not correct? A Constant phase difference at the point.  B Same amplitude at the point.  C Same frequency.  D Same speed.

Light of wavelength 600 nm is incident normally on a grating of slit spacing 2.0 × 10–6 m. A screen 1.50 m away shows the third-order maxima at the two ends. What is the distance between the two ends of the screen? A 1.4 m  B 2.7 m  C 3.1 m  D 6.2 m

A stationary wave forms from two progressive waves in opposite directions. Which statement about the progressive waves is NOT correct? A constant phase difference  B same frequency  C same wavelength  D same speed
A loudspeaker above a 60 cm tube forms a stationary wave with two nodes and two antinodes. Speed of sound 340 m s–1. What is the frequency? A 430 Hz  B 570 Hz  C 850 Hz  D 1700 Hz

A progressive water wave (ripple tank) passes a gap; gap width > wavelength. Which change increases spreading angle? A small decrease in wavelength  B small decrease in gap width  C small increase in frequency  D small increase in barrier height
Double-slit with monochromatic source L (vertical filament). Intensity at centre is I. One slit is covered. What is the intensity at the same point? A I/2  B I  C I/2^2  D I/4
Green light λ = 550 nm on a diffraction grating; screen 3.5 m away; third-order maximum is 0.75 m from centre. What is the slit spacing? A 2.6 × 10–6 m  B 7.7 × 10–6 m  C 7.9 × 10–6 m  D 1.0 × 10–5 m

Two progressive waves meet at a point. Which condition must be met for superposition to occur? A waves must be coherent  B waves must be same type  C waves must meet in opposite directions  D waves must meet in phase

A string between a vibration generator and a fixed point shows a stationary wave with five nodes at frequency f (node at the generator end). The frequency is increased slowly. What is the next frequency producing a stationary wave? A 1.25f  B 1.50f  C 1.75f  D 2.00f

Ripple tank with single gap shows diffraction. Initially, wavelength is five times smaller than gap. Which change increases diffraction? A double amplitude  B double gap width  C halve frequency  D halve wavelength

Laser light λ = 650 nm passes through two slits 0.12 mm apart; bright fringes on a parallel screen are 7.5 cm apart. What is the distance between the screen and the slits? A 1.4 m  B 2.8 m  C 7.0 m  D 14 m

Light from a laser is incident normally on a diffraction grating (line spacing 1.0 × 10–6 m). The angle between the two second-order maxima is 110°. What is the wavelength of the light? A 4.1 × 10–7 m  B 4.7 × 10–7 m  C 8.2 × 10–7 m  D 9.4 × 10–7 m

A stationary wave is set up in a stretched string. Which distance equals the wavelength? A double the distance between adjacent antinodes B half the distance between adjacent nodes C the distance between adjacent antinodes D the distance between a node and an adjacent antinode

Coherent light of frequency 1.5 × 10^12 Hz is incident on two slits P and Q, 80 mm apart; screen 4.0 m away. The sensor starts at central maximum, moves through two minima and two maxima, and stops at the middle of the third minimum. Which distance does it move? A 4.0 mm B 10 mm C 25 mm D 50 mm

A horizontal glass tube, closed at one end, has a layer of dust laid inside it on its lower side. Sound is emitted from a loudspeaker near the open end. The frequency is varied and, at one frequency, a stationary wave is formed so that the dust forms small heaps. The distance between four heaps of dust is 30 cm. The speed of sound in air in the tube is 330 m s–1. What is the frequency of the sound emitted by the loudspeaker?  A 1650 Hz  B 2200 Hz  C 3300 Hz  D 6600 Hz

Two waves superpose to form a resultant pattern. Which statement about the two waves must be correct? A They have the same amplitude.  B They are of the same type.  C They are transverse waves.  D They travel in opposite directions.

Laser light of wavelength 5.50 × 10⁻⁷ m is incident on a diffraction grating at the centre of a semicircular screen. A total of 9 bright dots appear on the screen. The grating line separation is d. What is a possible value of d? A 2.25 × 10⁻⁶ m  B 2.80 × 10⁻⁶ m  C 4.40 × 10⁻⁶ m  D 4.95 × 10⁻⁶ m
Microwaves are emitted from two sources at X and Y and meet at point Z. The waves from X and Y are coherent. What is a direct consequence of the two waves being coherent? (options A–D in the paper)

A stretched string PQ of length 1.2 m is fixed between a vibration generator and a wall, forming a stationary wave as shown in Fig. 5.2. (a) Explain how a stationary wave is formed between the vibration generator and the wall.
(b) Calculate the wavelength of the stationary wave shown in Fig. 5.2.

(c) Fig. 5.3 shows the stationary wave at time t = 0 when all points are at maximum displacement. The period of the wave is 0.16 s. On Fig. 5.3, sketch the shape of the stationary wave at time t = 0.24 s.

(e) Calculate the speed of the progressive waves on the stretched string.
Waves are emitted from two coherent sources. Which statement must be correct? A in phase  B transverse  C constant phase difference  D same amplitude

A screen at distance L from a grating (N total lines, spacing d) with light of wavelength λ incident. Which quantities affect the separation between first-order maxima on the screen? (Options show which of d, λ, L, N affect.)

A tube (node at mouthpiece, antinode at flared end) has lowest frequency 92 Hz. Which different frequencies can be produced? A 92, 138, 184, 230 Hz  B 92, 184, 276, 368 Hz  C 92, 276, 460, 644 Hz  D 92, 276, 828, 1288 Hz

(a)(i) Coherent visible light of a single frequency is incident normally on a double slit, producing bright and dark interference fringes on a screen (Fig. 6.1). Explain how this pattern is formed.

(b)(i) A stationary wave is formed on a stretched string AB (Fig. 6.2). P, Q and R are points on the string. On Fig. 6.2, draw a cross (×) to show the position of a node.

(b)(iii) State the phase difference between P and R.

A device containing a microwave emitter and receiver is placed in front of a large metal sheet in a vacuum as shown in Fig. 4.1. The line XY is perpendicular to the metal sheet. (b) (i) Calculate the wavelength of the microwaves.

The first time a minimum amplitude is detected by the receiver is when the device is at point Q. Determine the distance between P and Q.

What could not be used to create an electric current? A alpha-particles  B beta-particles  C neutrons  D protons

What is the definition of the potential difference (p.d.) across a component? A the energy transferred per unit charge  B the energy transferred per unit current  C the power transferred per unit charge  D the power transferred per unit current

The resistance of a filament lamp increases as the current in it increases. What is the reason for this? A The charge of each charge carrier increases.  B The potential difference across the filament decreases.  C The power dissipated by the filament decreases.  D The temperature of the filament increases.

A increases, 60 Ω  B decreases, 60 Ω  C increases, 100 Ω  D decreases, 100 Ω

Which equation can be obtained by applying Kirchhoff’s second law? A I0 = I1 = I2 = I3  B I0 = I1 + I2 + I3  C V0 = V1 = V2 = V3  D V0 = V1 + V2 + V3
